flowRoot.flowPara: * A study of plant productivity gradients across the
* Original C-only model (red, left figure), without N
limitation, are over-productive over all sites
* New model (green, left) includes N limitation,
reducing productivity for all sites, but shows little
* New model starts to capture observed relationships
*Tighter coupling of the atmosphere to the surface
-Increased consistency between UKCA (Gas & Aerosols) and JULES as more
-Deposition of trace species to oceans and cryosphere
*More process-based dry deposition schemes, eg. for aerosol species
*Allow for ‘bi-directional surface exchange’ schemes, with deposition,
*Designing a new framework for modelling dry deposition, JULES to pass
Global fire models typically described burnt area
as a consequence of fuel load, moisture, natural & anthropogenic ignition and land use suppression.
A lack of information on temporal & spatial distribution of these controls has meant their

impact is largely untested. Here, we map the limitation and sensitivity of burnt area to Fuel, Moisture, Ignitions and Suppression controls by optimizing a simple fire limitation model, using meteorological and remote sensed inputs, against monthly gridded burnt area.
* Changes in veg-snow interaction required to obtain correct ocean
- Changes in e.g sea ice give hints at impacts and teleconnections
- Exploring possible link with rapid climate change events in
* Using Bayesian inference technique to obtain observational constraints on the parameterization of tile albedo scheme (below)
Impact of including spatial variability and temporal acclimation of photosynthesis to temperature.

Changes in tropical land carbon uptake in climate model ensemble show biogeographical response is most important to explain present-day carbon uptake, with acclimation becoming more important in the future.
Mercado et al. "Large sensitivity in land carbon storage due to geographical and temporal variation in the thermal response of photosynthetic capacity." New Phytologist 2018
Rich Ellis1, Lina Mercado1,2, Emma Robinson1,
Douglas Clark1, Rebecca Oliver1, Garry Hayman1
1. NERC Centre for Ecology and Hydrology 2. University of Exeter
